DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower in quiet, late-morning trading in Europe today, and gold prices also fell. Traders attributed the dollar's weaker tone mostly to expectations that U.S. interest rates will decline further. ``It's a continuation of a trend already in place, but which has been renewed by expectation of easing U.S. monetary policy,'' said a trader in Milan, Italy. Traders said, however, that the market was very thin with activity limited to small, end-of-the-year commercial orders. The European markets were closed Monday and Tuesday for Christmas. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 142.10 yen, down 0.27 yen from Tuesday. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 141.85 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6885 West German marks, down from 1.7090 _1.5310 Swiss francs, down from 1.5475 _5.7750 French francs, down from 5.8385 _1.9110 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9330 _1,266.00 Italian lire, down from 1,277.75 _1.1590 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1585 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6305 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6205 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $408.40 a troy ounce, down from $412.25 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $409.45. In Zurich, the bid price was $409.45, down from $413.00 bid late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong fell to close at a bid $408.49, down $3.28 from Saturday. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.53 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.58.
